title: Axios
text:
What's happening: By early Monday, the difficult conditions meant just 5% of the massive Kincade Fire was contained, with some 54,298 acres burned in Sonoma County, per CalFire.

The nearly 3,000 firefighters fighting the blaze have had trouble traversing the hilly rural areas of the county in which the blaze has spread, the New York Times reports.

The National Weather Service issued a red-flag warning — signaling a dangerous combination of heavy winds and low humidity — in all or part of at least 30 Northern California counties on Sunday.

PG&E began to cut power to 940,000 properties in a new round of shutdowns on Saturday.

What they're saying: Newsom said at a news conference on Saturday, "The next 72 hours is going to be challenging. I could sugarcoat it, but I'm not [going to]."

Michael Lewis, Pacific Gas and Electric (PG&E)'s senior vice president of electric operations, said, "This wind event is forecast to be the most serious weather situation that Northern and Central California has experienced in recent memory."

The big picture: PG&E, the largest utility in the state, turned off the electricity twice in recent weeks, aiming to prevent wildfires during high-wind periods and dry spells. PG&E's latest round of shut-offs was expected to occur in stages.

PG&E has been criticized by lawmakers for the way it has handled the power shutdowns. Newsom said at Saturday's news conference that "the scale and scope" of the firm's blackout decision "is clearly unacceptable."

State Sen. Jerry Hill (D-San Mateo), who's been appointed to a panel reviewing the PG&E blackouts, told the Times that the courts should "take control of the company before more damage is done."
